drtn.game

Class GameEngine

  • java.lang.Object
    • drtn.game.GameEngine

extends java.lang.Object

      static class  GameEngine.State
      Encodes possible play-states These are not to be confused with the game-state (which is directly linked to the renderer)

      Begins "Catch the Chancellor" mini-game

      Getter for the chancellor object of the game
      void claimTile()
      Claims the last tile to have been selected on the main GameScreen for the active player This grants them the ability to plant a Roboticon on it and yield resources from it for themselves Specifically registers the selected tile under the object holding the active player's data, re-colours its border for owner identification purposes and moves the game on to the next player/phase

      Closes the market interface, thereby preventing transactions from taking place

      Closes the trade overlay

      Returns the data pertaining to the player who is active at the time when this is called

      Returns the ID of the player who is active at the time when this is called

      Deploys a Roboticon on the last tile to have been selected Draws a Roboticon from the active player's Roboticon count and assigns it to the tile in question

      Sets the currently selected tile to null

      Getter for the latest trade offer that has been sent

      Returns all of the data pertaining to the game's market, which is declared and managed by the engine

      Advances the game's progress upon call Acts as a state machine of sorts, moving the game from one phase to another depending on what phase it is currently at when this method is called.
      void openResourceMarketInterface()
      Opens the market's interface up to allow for ore, energy and food to be bought and sold through it This does not necessarily allow for roboticons to be bought
      void openRoboticonMarketInterface()
      Opens the market's interface up to allow for roboticons to be bought from it This does not necessarily allow for ore, energy or food to be bought or sold
      void pauseGame()
      Pauses the game and opens the pause-menu (which is just a sub-stage in the GameScreen class) Specifically pauses the game's timer and marks the engine's internal play-state to [State.PAUSE]
      int phase()
      Return's the game's phase as a number between (or possibly one of) 1 and 5
      Player[] players()
      Returns all of the data pertaining to the array of players managed by the game's engine Unless the game's architecture changes radically, this should only ever return two Player objects
      void refreshAuctionConfirmationButtonAvailability()
      Verifies whether the pending trade request can indeed be sent (by checking whether it has offerings and a non-zero price-tag) and - if so - enables the button that would allow for the active player to send that request
      void refreshAuctionPriceButtonAvailability()
      Updates the price-adjustment buttons in the auction house's interface based on how much money the pending request's target still has to spare
      void refreshMarketButtonAvailability()
      Updates the options that are made available to the active player through the market's interface (based on what is owned by both the player and the market itself at the current time)
      void refreshUpgradeOverlay()
      Updates the upgrade overlay to display the yield and roboticon levels of the last tile to have been selected
      void removeTrade(Trade trade)
      Removes a specific trade from the pool of pending trades
      void resetAuctionInterface()
      Resets the appearance of the auction house's interface Usually called to ensure that players can never offer more then they actually have at prices which other players may simply not be able to afford
      void resumeGame()
      Resumes the game and re-opens the primary in-game inteface Specifically increments the in-game timer by 1 second, restarts it and marks the engine's internal play-state to [State.PAUSE] Note that the timer is incremented by 1 second to circumvent a bug that causes it to lose 1 second whenever it's restarted
      Tile selectedTile()
      Returns the data pertaining to the last Tile that was selected by a player
      void setAuctionButtonFunctions()
      Assigns functions to the buttons that comprise the auction-house's interface, thereby allowing players to set up trade-offers
      void setMarketButtonFunctions()
      Sets the functions of all the buttons within the market's interface (to facilitate purchases and sales)
      void setUpgradeOverlayButtonFunctions()
      Assigns functions to the buttons in the upgrade overlay, thereby enabling roboticon upgrades to occur
      GameEngine.State state()
      Return's the game's current play-state, which can either be [State.RUN] or [State.PAUSE] This is not to be confused with the game-state (which is directly linked to the renderer)
      void stopChancellorMode()
      Stops the "Catch the Chancellor" mini-game
      void testTrade()
      Tests whether there is a trade currently pending
      Tile[] tiles()
      Collectively returns every Tile managed by the engine in array
      void updateCurrentPlayer(Player currentPlayer)
      Updates the data pertaining to the game's current player This is used by the Market class to process item transactions
      void updateSelectedTileObject(Tile tile)
      Setter fo the currently selected tile
      void upgradeRoboticon(int resource)
      Function for upgrading a particular level of the roboticon stored on the last tile to have been selected

    • Field Detail

      • tiles

        public Tile[] tiles
        Array holding the tiles to be laid over the map Note that the tiles' visuals are encoded by the image declared and stored in the GameScreen class (and not here)

    • Constructor Detail

      • GameEngine

        public GameEngine(com.badlogic.gdx.Game game,
                  GameScreen gameScreen)
        Constructs the game's engine. Imports the game's state (for direct renderer access) and the data held by the GameScreen which this engine directly controls; then goes on to set up player-data for the game's players, tile-data for the on-screen map and the in-game market for in-play manipulation. In the cases of the latter two tasks, the engine directly interacts with the GameScreen object imported to it (as a parameter of this constructor) so that it can draw the visual interfaces for the game's market and tiles directly to the game's primary interface.
        Parameters:
        game - Variable storing the game's state
        gameScreen - The object encoding the in-game interface which is to be controlled by this engine

    • Method Detail

      • getInstance

        public static GameEngine getInstance()
        Getter for the instance of the GameEngine
        Returns:
        The GameEngine object

      • updateSelectedTileObject

        public void updateSelectedTileObject(Tile tile)
        Setter fo the currently selected tile
        Parameters:
        tile - The tile that has been selected

      • deselectTile

        public void deselectTile()
        Sets the currently selected tile to null

      • nextPhase

        public void nextPhase()
        Advances the game's progress upon call Acts as a state machine of sorts, moving the game from one phase to another depending on what phase it is currently at when this method is called. If player 1 is the current player in any particular phase, then the phase number remains and control is handed off to the other player: otherwise, control returns to player 1 and the game advances to the next state, implementing any state-specific features as it goes. PHASE 1: Acquisition of Tiles PHASE 2: Acquisition of Roboticons PHASE 3: Placement of Roboticons PHASE 4: Production of Resources by Roboticons PHASE 5: Market Trading

      • pauseGame

        public void pauseGame()
        Pauses the game and opens the pause-menu (which is just a sub-stage in the GameScreen class) Specifically pauses the game's timer and marks the engine's internal play-state to [State.PAUSE]

      • resumeGame

        public void resumeGame()
        Resumes the game and re-opens the primary in-game inteface Specifically increments the in-game timer by 1 second, restarts it and marks the engine's internal play-state to [State.PAUSE] Note that the timer is incremented by 1 second to circumvent a bug that causes it to lose 1 second whenever it's restarted

      • claimTile

        public void claimTile()
        Claims the last tile to have been selected on the main GameScreen for the active player This grants them the ability to plant a Roboticon on it and yield resources from it for themselves Specifically registers the selected tile under the object holding the active player's data, re-colours its border for owner identification purposes and moves the game on to the next player/phase

      • deployRoboticon

        public void deployRoboticon()
        Deploys a Roboticon on the last tile to have been selected Draws a Roboticon from the active player's Roboticon count and assigns it to the tile in question

      • beginChancellorMode

        public void beginChancellorMode()
        Begins "Catch the Chancellor" mini-game

      • stopChancellorMode

        public void stopChancellorMode()
        Stops the "Catch the Chancellor" mini-game

      • state

        public GameEngine.State state()
        Return's the game's current play-state, which can either be [State.RUN] or [State.PAUSE] This is not to be confused with the game-state (which is directly linked to the renderer)
        Returns:
        State The game's current play-state

      • phase

        public int phase()
        Return's the game's phase as a number between (or possibly one of) 1 and 5
        Returns:
        int The game's current phase

      • players

        public Player[] players()
        Returns all of the data pertaining to the array of players managed by the game's engine Unless the game's architecture changes radically, this should only ever return two Player objects
        Returns:
        Player[] An array of all Player objects (encapsulating player-data) managed by the engine

      • currentPlayer

        public Player currentPlayer()
        Returns the data pertaining to the player who is active at the time when this is called
        Returns:
        Player The current user's Player object, encoding all of their data

      • tiles

        public Tile[] tiles()

        Tile[] An array of all Tile objects (encapsulating tile-data) managed by the engine

        public void updateCurrentPlayer(Player currentPlayer)

      • upgradeRoboticon

        public void upgradeRoboticon(int resource)
        Function for upgrading a particular level of the roboticon stored on the last tile to have been selected
        Parameters:
        resource - The type of resource which the roboticon will gather more of {0: ore | 1: energy | 2: food}

      • refreshMarketButtonAvailability

        public void refreshMarketButtonAvailability()
        Updates the options that are made available to the active player through the market's interface (based on what is owned by both the player and the market itself at the current time)

      • openResourceMarketInterface

        public void openResourceMarketInterface()
        Opens the market's interface up to allow for ore, energy and food to be bought and sold through it This does not necessarily allow for roboticons to be bought

      • openRoboticonMarketInterface

        public void openRoboticonMarketInterface()
        Opens the market's interface up to allow for roboticons to be bought from it This does not necessarily allow for ore, energy or food to be bought or sold

      • closeMarketInterface

        public void closeMarketInterface()
        Closes the market interface, thereby preventing transactions from taking place

      • resetAuctionInterface

        public void resetAuctionInterface()
        Resets the appearance of the auction house's interface Usually called to ensure that players can never offer more then they actually have at prices which other players may simply not be able to afford

      • setAuctionButtonFunctions

        public void setAuctionButtonFunctions()
        Assigns functions to the buttons that comprise the auction-house's interface, thereby allowing players to set up trade-offers

      • setUpgradeOverlayButtonFunctions

        public void setUpgradeOverlayButtonFunctions()
        Assigns functions to the buttons in the upgrade overlay, thereby enabling roboticon upgrades to occur

      • refreshUpgradeOverlay

        public void refreshUpgradeOverlay()
        Updates the upgrade overlay to display the yield and roboticon levels of the last tile to have been selected

      • refreshAuctionPriceButtonAvailability

        public void refreshAuctionPriceButtonAvailability()
        Updates the price-adjustment buttons in the auction house's interface based on how much money the pending request's target still has to spare

      • refreshAuctionConfirmationButtonAvailability

        public void refreshAuctionConfirmationButtonAvailability()
        Verifies whether the pending trade request can indeed be sent (by checking whether it has offerings and a non-zero price-tag) and - if so - enables the button that would allow for the active player to send that request
